ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write a better essay- form a strong argument and structure an organized essay. I learned how to compare arguments from other sources. I developed the skill of having discussions about texts.

I gained a much better understanding into the development of the "work life" throughout time. We traveled from early days to present day exploring what grievances people had with work and how overwork was at the time.
I learned how to write an essay with more ease. I also learned how to formulate an academic argument.
How to analyze readings critically, have engaging discussions with classmates, learn to write a research paper along with other shorter assignments
My writing improved a lot. My analysis improved. I became more knowledgable about the course topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Too much work that is rushed, not enough feedback to get better as a writer overall

I wish we had a little more time to think and engage with what we were writing about sometimes. I really enjoyed the material that we read and thought that it all was well curated. The essays helped me further engage with the material we read. The class discussions were also very helpful in understanding material and practicing having intellectual conversation. I felt that the peer review sessions though were not as helpful, sometimes yes but often the feedback I received was surface level.
This class was fast paced, but it still managed to explore ideas for a long enough time to understand it.

Strengths: the readings we did in class were very engaging and exciting, and I could relate them back to my own life. Professor Ellermann also pushed us to think critically about the readings and think from other points of view. I appreciated how the longest assignment (the research paper) was not our last assignment which made balancing the workload from other classes during the last two weeks of classes much better.

Weaknesses: not sure this is a weakness per se, since this is an introductory writing course that would need a lot of writing, but it did feel like we always had an assignment to work on and there was rarely any time to breathe.
Essays seemed to be right after each other so very quick

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The sociology aspect of the content is very real and easy to see how it affects ones daily life so it is very engaging. Anyone who wants to get better at writing should take this class.
I would highly recommend this class. The topics that were covered have knowledge that can be used by anyone. That and the class was well taught.
Definitely would recommend to anyone trying to improve their writing skills.

Yes, I think an ENGL 114 course is very valuable to students looking to improve their writing skills. It is certainly not easy, and there will be a lot of writing, but you will get better. I would highly recommend making sure that you are truly interested in the topic of the course because otherwise ENGL 114 will be a large pain. I would highly recommend The Right To Be Lazy and Professor Ellermann in particular; the topic was incredibly engaging and Prof. Ellermann is knowledgeable and excited about the topic and provides clear feedback that pushes you to grow.
Yes, I learned a lot about the nature of work, and it challenged my beliefs.

extras.title: ENGL 114 12 - The Right to Be Lazy
